entry.title: Game: Spelunky (XBLA, 2012) (2)
entry.content:
Game: Spelunky (XBLA, 2012) (2)20130210
I played for about an hour today and switched to using my arcade
stick so that I know how to. My wife and I talked about trying the
local co-op, but I only have one normal Xbox controller, so she'll
have to use that. Playing with stick feels like it forces me to
move a bit slower and methodically, which is good. I think the
hardest thing to do is run which, again, is a good thing.

I got to the Jungle two times in my little play session and was
able to unlock the short-cut to it.  I read a bit of a FAQ about
the achievements and they are very intimidating. I feel like I
will just want to beat it normally. I'm not sure if I should try
to play through it from the start always or use the
short-cuts. The short-cuts are a nice way to feel like you're
making progress definitely, but it also seems like you are denying
yourself the ability to gather resources from the early stages.

I like using the Compass and bombs to get to the bottom quickly.

--

In the evening, I played for about 45 minutes, most of the time
with my wife. We found playing two player to be very
frustrating. The game requires a lot of coordination and it is
easy to make a mistake that totally disrupts the other
player---particularly because the camera follows the first
player. For example, if you accidentally fall or get shot, you
are likely to force scroll the screen and kill them. Not a recipe
for marital bliss.

entry.content:
Game: Fez (XBLA, 2012) (2)20130208
This afternoon I played for about three hours and made a lot of
discoveries. I discovered the Tetromino code and got the Telescope
worked out. I was also able to use one of the pillars and do the
door room. Finding the Tetris code was awesome because there was
so much I could do with it. Just before I finished that session, I
found the Rosetta Stone of the alphabet... although so far I
haven't found any useful text.

Later in the day I played again and found the number code and then
got to the ancient city. (I had been exploring the world and never
going to back to the waterfall area.) Something funny happened, I
had already got 32 cubes before getting to the city and Dot said
something about going back to a door there. I explored it and
inadvertently beat the game. I was nervous when I saw New Game+,
because I didn't want to get everything again, but was glad that I
just got the sunglasses.

I played for another two hours and got a lot more, including the
many Tuning Forks. Right now I have just got through the Lava
area... which was terrifying. I don't have another key to use in
the Sewer, so I'm nervous that I'll to find my way back here.

I've continued to find the platforming to be fun and the puzzley
aspects of the game to be nice. I think the alphabet is a bit
over-kill because it is just so painful to translate anything. I'd
much prefer giving proof that I know what it means and then having
the game auto-translate or something.

entry.title: Game: Fez (XBLA, 2012)
entry.content:
Game: Fez (XBLA, 2012)20130207
I downloaded and start this game this morning. I got about 10
cubes and a bunch of bits. I like the game so far. The platforming
is fine and the environmental puzzles are not too tricky, but
interesting enough. I though the opening was very clever and the
concept is cute. I get the feeling that I will become annoyed with
the inability to travel quickly between places I've been before
and the inability to refer to locations by name. The map, since it
is a non-planar graph, is very confusing and not very helpful.

I have taken some notes of the signs I see, but haven't gotten at
all close to deciphering anything.

--

I played for another two and a half hours tonight. I have over
twenty normal cubes and I got three anti-cubes: the first from the
QR code and the other two from around the clock. The platforming
has gotten more challenging and interesting. I quite like that the
map shows when there is a "secret" somewhere you have not
completed.

In the creepy area, there was this set of doors that seemed to be
confusingly placed. I mapped everything out but didn't get
anywhere. Later, I realized that I had treasure maps on me that
showed some stuff related to that area, but it also had symbols I
haven't figured out yet.

The area near the clock is interesting because it feels like a
place where other dimensional shifters lived. I feel like I'll
have to go back there a lot.

Still annoyed at the lack of fast travel. Also, the game crashed
once. Lame. I would have stopped playing if I lost anything, but
didn't, so that's good.

entry.title: Game: Tales of Graces f (PS3, 2010) (32)
entry.content:
Game: Tales of Graces f (PS3, 2010) (32)20130207
I looked up the stats on my New Game+. I ended with Asbel at level
80, which is crazy to me, because I was roughly that level after
getting to Zhonecage (after almost 100 hours) the first time. I
had 518 encounters in the New Game+, the total battle time was 48
minutes, which means the average battle length was 5.5 seconds!
It's also pretty amazing to me that only 9% of my play time was
fighting this time, especially because I skipped every cut-scene,
had 2x movement speed, and was just running from boss to boss.

I've decided that I'm done with the game. The only things left
that I could do is (a) get all the Carta cards, which would be
super tedious; (b) get the Turtlez Togz from the Dark Turtlez,
which would be super tedious; (c) get the Eleth Mixer to 9999,
which even checking out what apparently is the fastest way to do
it, would be crazy; and, (d) get the title trophies for the men,
which would probably be painful because it mean having lots of
battles and managing what skills they used.

This was a very fun game. The battle system is great and the story
is a lot of fun. The world is cool too. I think my only complaints
about it are very minor: the user interface on some things could
have been better. For example, being able to have sets of AI
settings for different situations, sets of mixer settings as well,
and being able to pick a result you wanted from the dualizing
system (that you had already discovered) rather than having to
remember the recipe in your head. The AI was also pretty
unreliable as a healer. I found that it almost never tried to
resurrect dead characters and if you told it to, then it was hit,
it would not remember what your last instruction was. This was
very annoying.
